rGSTUx-y6.memHandModelNotes:
Brackish/Salt water type was selected for this species, but since water is selected as a map unit, this should serve to limit this species' model to Brackish/Salt water habitats.  I therefore un-selected water type from the drop-down menu above. MJR 29aug07.

Added FW and SW 120m and 9999 (unlimited) FROM and INTO buffers respectively. MJR 30 January 2008.

habitat_description:
The range of the green sea turtle is primarily pantropical in the Pacific, Indian, and Atlantic oceans. Due to drifting ocean currents and higher than normal temperatures, this species sometimes is found in higher temperate latitudes. This transition is regarded also to be a normal life history event. Major nesting sites are Ascencion Island, Aves Island, in Costa Rica, and in Surinam (Natureserve.org ). In the U. S. Atlantic waters, this species is found around Puerto Rico, Virgin Islands, and from Texas to Massachusetts. Florida represents a minor nesting region; nonetheless it occurs in St. Lucie, Palm Beach, Volusia, Dade, Martin, Santa Rosa, Indian River, Brevard, and Broward counties. Rare occurrences of nesting sites are apparent in Georgia, Texas, and North Carolina. Major feeding areas in Florida are located in Florida Bay, Indian River, Homossassa Bay, Cedar Key, and Crystal River (Collazo et al. 1992; Ehrhart and Witherington 1992; Natureserve.org).

Feeding usually takes place in low energy water with submerged vegetation, shallow waters, and in convergence zones in the open oceans. Basking is sometimes observed on beaches of some areas (e. g. Hawaii). Rocky outcrops and coral reefs in proximity to feeding pastures are simultaneously used as resting areas. Other resting areas, especially for the winter, include the bottom of the northern Gulf of California (Natureserve.org). Nesting sites are located on beaches usually on islands. Sand in these sites varies from coarse to fine usually with little organic content. Most nesting areas are found in high energy beaches with deep sand (Allard et al. 1994; Meylan et al. 1990; Natureserve.org). Urban development around beaches and illumination creates unsuitable conditions for nesting; hatchlings are often seen floating in masses of Sargassum in convergence zones (Natureserve.org).
